title: Isaiah Chapter 65 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 65 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 65 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 65.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 65:1, to whom did God say, 'Behold me, behold me'?
options: A nation that was not called by my name
The children of Israel
The priests in the temple
The kings of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: A nation that was not called by my name
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:1 states God said, 'Behold me, behold me, unto a nation that was not called by my name.'

questions.question: What did God say He had spread out all day to a rebellious people in Isaiah 65:2?
options: His hands
His wings
His words
His law
questions.correctAnswer: His hands
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:2 says, 'I have spread out my hands all the day unto a rebellious people.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 65:3, where did the people burn incense?
options: Upon altars of brick
In the temple
On mountain tops
In their homes
questions.correctAnswer: Upon altars of brick
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:3 mentions they 'burneth incense upon altars of brick.'

questions.question: In Isaiah 65:4, what kind of flesh did the people eat that was considered abominable?
options: Swine's flesh
Fish
Lamb
Goat
questions.correctAnswer: Swine's flesh
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:4 states they 'eat swine's flesh, and broth of abominable things is in their vessels.'

questions.question: What did the people say to each other according to Isaiah 65:5?
options: Stand by thyself, come not near to me
Let us worship together
Come and eat
Bless the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: Stand by thyself, come not near to me
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:5 records them saying, 'Stand by thyself, come not near to me; for I am holier than thou.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 65:6 says God will keep silence about the people's sins.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:6 says, 'I will not keep silence, but will recompense,' meaning God will not stay silent about their sins.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 65:7, whose iniquities will God measure into their bosom?
options: The people's and their fathers' iniquities
Only the people's iniquities
Only the kings' iniquities
The iniquities of the nations
questions.correctAnswer: The people's and their fathers' iniquities
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:7 states God will recompense 'Your iniquities, and the iniquities of your fathers together.'

questions.question: What will God create according to Isaiah 65:17?
options: New heavens and a new earth
A new temple
New mountains and rivers
A new people
questions.correctAnswer: New heavens and a new earth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:17 states, 'For, behold, I create new heavens and a new earth.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 65:20 says the child shall die an hundred years old.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:20 clearly states, 'the child shall die an hundred years old.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 65:21, what will the people build and plant?
options: Houses and vineyards
Temples and gardens
Walls and olive trees
Forts and grain fields
questions.correctAnswer: Houses and vineyards
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:21 says, 'And they shall build houses, and inhabit them; and they shall plant vineyards.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The wolf and the lamb shall feed together, and the lion shall eat _____ like the bullock' (Isaiah 65:25).
options: straw
grass
meat
hay
questions.correctAnswer: straw
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:25 states, 'and the lion shall eat straw like the bullock.'

questions.question: Who shall inherit the mountains according to Isaiah 65:9?
options: Mine elect and my servants
The kings of the earth
The rebellious people
The priests
questions.correctAnswer: Mine elect and my servants
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:9 says, 'mine elect shall inherit it, and my servants shall dwell there.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 65:13, what will happen to those who forsake the Lord?
options: They shall be hungry and thirsty
They shall be rich and blessed
They shall inherit the land
They shall sing for joy
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be hungry and thirsty
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:13 states, 'my servants shall eat, but ye shall be hungry: my servants shall drink, but ye shall be thirsty.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 65:24 states that God will answer before they call and hear while they speak.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:24 says, 'before they call, I will answer; and while they are yet speaking, I will hear.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 65:11, what have the people prepared a table for?
options: That troop
The Lord
The elders
The prophets
questions.correctAnswer: That troop
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:11 says, 'that prepare a table for that troop.'

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 65 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 65 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to trust God during difficult times. Based on Isaiah 65, what truth can you share about God's response to those who seek Him?
options: God is found by those who did not seek Him
God ignores those who do not follow the law strictly
God only answers the prayers of the righteous
God punishes those who doubt Him
questions.correctAnswer: God is found by those who did not seek Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:1 shows that God is sought and found even by those who did not initially seek Him, demonstrating His grace and openness to all who turn to Him. This is supported by verses 8 and 9 which speak of God's blessings on His servants.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 65 teach us about the importance of obedience to God’s ways rather than following our own thoughts?
options: Rebellion causes God’s anger and judgment
Following our own thoughts leads to blessings
Obedience is optional for God’s servants
God rewards only external sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Rebellion causes God’s anger and judgment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:2-3 highlights that rebellious people who follow their own thoughts provoke God's anger, showing the necessity of obedience rather than self-guidance. This is consistent with verses 6 and 7 about recompense for iniquities.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged because others around them practice improper worship. According to Isaiah 65, how should they understand God's view of such behavior?
options: God is angered by false sacrifices and blasphemy
God accepts all forms of worship equally
God ignores worship done in gardens
God prefers worship with brick altars
questions.correctAnswer: God is angered by false sacrifices and blasphemy
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:3-7 condemns those who offer sacrifices improperly and blaspheme God, indicating that true worship must be sincere and obedient. God's recompense for such actions is declared in verses 6 and 7.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 65 encourage believers regarding the legacy and inheritance God promises?
options: God’s elect will inherit His mountains and dwell there
Inheritance is based on earthly wealth only
Only the oldest will receive God's promises
Inheritance depends on human strength
questions.correctAnswer: God’s elect will inherit His mountains and dwell there
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:9-10 speaks of God bringing forth a seed from Jacob and Judah who will inherit His mountains and dwell securely, illustrating God's promise of blessing and inheritance for His faithful servants.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 65 teach about the consequences of forsaking the Lord and forgetting His holy mountain?
options: Those who forsake God will face judgment and hunger
They will receive more blessings than the faithful
God will remain silent towards their actions
They will be honored among the people
questions.correctAnswer: Those who forsake God will face judgment and hunger
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:11-14 describes how those who forsake the Lord will be numbered to the sword, face hunger, thirst, shame, sorrow, and vexation, contrasting the blessings promised to God’s servants.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with discouragement because of past sins. Based on Isaiah 65, what hope can you share about God’s forgiveness and new beginnings?
options: God creates new heavens and a new earth where former troubles are forgotten
God remembers all past sins forever without mercy
God punishes without end for former troubles
Only earthly changes can bring new beginnings
questions.correctAnswer: God creates new heavens and a new earth where former troubles are forgotten
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:16-17 teaches that God will create new heavens and a new earth, and former troubles will not be remembered, offering hope of forgiveness and renewal for His people.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 65 instruct believers to respond in their daily work and labor?
options: They shall not labor in vain because they are blessed by the LORD
Their labor will always bring trouble and frustration
They should avoid working to avoid disappointment
Labor is meaningless without earthly reward
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not labor in vain because they are blessed by the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:23 highlights that God's blessed seed will not labor in vain, emphasizing the value and blessing of faithful work and perseverance in daily life.

questions.question: A believer is praying but feels unheard. According to Isaiah 65, what assurance can you give about God’s attentiveness to prayer?
options: God answers before they call and hears while they speak
God only answers prayers after a long time
God ignores prayers that are not public
God answers only if they are perfect
questions.correctAnswer: God answers before they call and hears while they speak
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:24 assures that God will answer His people even before they call and will hear them while they are still speaking, encouraging trust in God's responsiveness to prayer.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 65 illustrate the peace and harmony that God will establish among His people?
options: The wolf and lamb will feed together, and no harm will be done
Animals will continue to fight and cause destruction
Only humans will experience peace, not animals
Peace will come only after complete judgment
questions.correctAnswer: The wolf and lamb will feed together, and no harm will be done
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:25 describes a future peace where natural enemies coexist peacefully, symbolizing the harmony God will bring to His holy mountain and people.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 65, God will bless those who bless themselves on earth by blessing themselves in the God of truth.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:16 states that those who bless themselves in the earth shall bless themselves in the God of truth, indicating the importance of honoring God in all things.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 65 teaches that God will remain silent and not repay the iniquities of those who provoke Him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:6 clearly states that God will not keep silence but will recompense even into their bosom, showing that God holds people accountable for their actions.

questions.question: Fill-in-the-blank: Isaiah 65 says, 'And they shall build houses, and _______ them; and they shall plant vineyards, and eat the fruit of them.'
options: inhabit
destroy
sell
leave
questions.correctAnswer: inhabit
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:21 promises that God's people will build houses and inhabit them, showing stability and blessing in their work and life.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 65 teach about humility and pride through the example of those who say, 'I am holier than thou'?
options: Such pride is like smoke in God's nose and a fire that burns all day
God favors those who boast of their holiness
Pride leads to greater acceptance by God
Humility is unnecessary if one follows rituals
questions.correctAnswer: Such pride is like smoke in God's nose and a fire that burns all day
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:5 condemns those who pridefully claim to be holier than others, describing their attitude as offensive to God, teaching the value of humility.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 65 encourage believers to rejoice in God’s creation and promises?
options: Be glad and rejoice forever in what God creates, like Jerusalem and her people
Focus on past troubles rather than future joy
Rejoicing is only for select leaders
Joy is temporary and should be avoided
questions.correctAnswer: Be glad and rejoice forever in what God creates, like Jerusalem and her people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:18-19 encourages believers to rejoice forever in God's new creation, highlighting the joy God takes in His people and the city of Jerusalem.

questions.question: A believer wonders about the longevity and quality of life in God's kingdom. Based on Isaiah 65, what biblical truth can you share?
options: The child shall die an hundred years old, and the sinner at a hundred shall be accursed
Everyone will live forever without death
Longevity depends on wealth and power
Life will be short but joyful
questions.correctAnswer: The child shall die an hundred years old, and the sinner at a hundred shall be accursed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:20 describes the longevity and quality of life where the righteous live long, but sinners face judgment, teaching accountability and hope for God's kingdom.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 65 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 65.

questions.question: In Isaiah 65:1, to whom does the LORD say He was sought and found?
options: A nation not called by His name
The children of Israel only
The priests and Levites
The righteous among the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: A nation not called by His name
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:1 states that God was sought of those who did not ask for Him and found by those who did not seek Him, specifically ‘unto a nation that was not called by my name,’ indicating Gentiles or outsiders.

questions.question: What imagery does Isaiah 65:2 use to describe God's relationship with the rebellious people?
options: Spreading out His hands all day
Pouring out rain upon the earth
Building a mighty fortress
Carrying them upon His shoulders
questions.correctAnswer: Spreading out His hands all day
questions.explanation: The verse uses the image of God spreading out His hands all day to a rebellious people, symbolizing His long-suffering invitation despite their disobedience.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 65:3, what kind of places did the rebellious people use for their sacrifices?
options: Gardens and altars of brick
The temple in Jerusalem
High mountains and caves
The riverbanks and open fields
questions.correctAnswer: Gardens and altars of brick
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:3 mentions that the rebellious people sacrificed in gardens and burned incense on altars made of brick, a practice condemned as improper worship.

questions.question: Which forbidden food is mentioned in Isaiah 65:4 as being eaten by those who provoke God?
options: Swine's flesh
Locusts
Shellfish
Horse meat
questions.correctAnswer: Swine's flesh
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:4 explicitly mentions that the rebellious people eat swine’s flesh, which was considered unclean according to Mosaic Law.

questions.question: In Isaiah 65:5, what metaphor does God use to describe those who say 'I am holier than thou'?
options: A smoke in my nose, a fire that burneth all the day
A thorn in my side, a stone in my shoe
A shadow at noon, a cloud without rain
A serpent in the grass, a wolf in sheep's clothing
questions.correctAnswer: A smoke in my nose, a fire that burneth all the day
questions.explanation: The verse uses the imagery of smoke and continuous fire to describe the irritation and anger provoked by hypocritical holiness claims.

questions.question: What is the divine response to the sins of the people and their ancestors as stated in Isaiah 65:7?
options: God will measure their former work into their bosom
God will forgive them and forget their sins
God will send prophets to guide them
God will exile them to a foreign land
questions.correctAnswer: God will measure their former work into their bosom
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:7 declares that God will recompense their iniquities, measuring their former works into their bosom, indicating judgment and retribution.

questions.question: Isaiah 65:8 uses the metaphor of new wine found in a cluster to illustrate what divine action?
options: Preserving a blessing for His servants
Destroying all the unfaithful
Pouring out wrath upon the nations
Harvesting the grapes of judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Preserving a blessing for His servants
questions.explanation: The verse compares God’s mercy to not destroying new wine in a cluster, symbolizing His intention to spare and bless His faithful servants.

questions.question: What future inheritance is promised in Isaiah 65:9?
options: A seed out of Jacob and an inheritor out of Judah
The throne of David forever
The land of Egypt and Cush
A kingdom in the heavens
questions.correctAnswer: A seed out of Jacob and an inheritor out of Judah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:9 foretells God bringing forth a seed from Jacob and Judah who will inherit His mountains, a promise of restoration to the faithful.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 65:10 describe the future condition of Sharon and the valley of Achor?
options: A fold of flocks and a place for herds to lie down
A desert wasteland
A battlefield for the nations
A city of merchants and traders
questions.correctAnswer: A fold of flocks and a place for herds to lie down
questions.explanation: The verse portrays these places as peaceful grazing grounds for God's people, symbolizing prosperity and peace.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 65:11, what have the people forsaken?
options: The LORD and His holy mountain
The laws of Moses
The covenant of Abraham
The temple sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD and His holy mountain
questions.explanation: The verse condemns those who forsake the LORD and forget His holy mountain, referring to Jerusalem and proper worship.

questions.question: What consequence is declared in Isaiah 65:12 for those who did not respond when God called?
options: They will be numbered to the sword and bow down to slaughter
They will be forgiven and restored
They will be exiled to Babylon
They will be given a second chance
questions.correctAnswer: They will be numbered to the sword and bow down to slaughter
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:12 warns of judgment by the sword upon those who ignored God's call and chose evil.

questions.question: Which future blessing contrasts the hunger and thirst of the wicked in Isaiah 65:13?
options: My servants shall eat, drink, and rejoice
My servants shall fast and pray
My servants shall wander in the wilderness
My servants shall build great cities
questions.correctAnswer: My servants shall eat, drink, and rejoice
questions.explanation: The verse contrasts the fate of the wicked with God’s servants who will be satisfied and joyful.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 65:17 predicts that the former things will be remembered and mourned.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:17 explicitly states that God will create new heavens and a new earth, and the former things shall not be remembered nor come into mind.

questions.question: What is the significance of the name change mentioned in Isaiah 65:15?
options: God will call His servants by another name, leaving the wicked's name as a curse
The people will adopt foreign names
The priests will rename the cities
The kings will change their titles
questions.correctAnswer: God will call His servants by another name, leaving the wicked's name as a curse
questions.explanation: The verse indicates a divine re-identification of God's servants, contrasting with the cursed names left by the wicked.

questions.question: Isaiah 65:25 depicts a peaceful coexistence of animals symbolic of what future reality?
options: Harmony and peace on God's holy mountain
A return to the wilderness
A new creation filled with wild beasts
The end of animal sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Harmony and peace on God's holy mountain
questions.explanation: The verse describes natural enemies feeding together and no harm occurring, symbolizing messianic peace and restoration.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 65 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 65 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 65:1, how does God describe His revelation to the people who did not seek Him?
options: He was sought by those who did not ask for Him
He was hidden from those who sought Him
He only revealed Himself to His chosen nation
He remained silent to the unworthy
questions.correctAnswer: He was sought by those who did not ask for Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:1 states God was 'sought of them that asked not for me; I am found of them that sought me not,' showing God's initiative in revealing Himself even to those who did not actively seek Him. This theme is echoed in Romans 10:20 where Paul quotes Isaiah, and also seen in John 6:44 where Jesus teaches that no one can come to Him unless drawn by the Father.

questions.question: What is the nature of the people God addresses in Isaiah 65:2?
options: A rebellious people who follow their own thoughts
A humble people seeking God’s will
A faithful remnant who obey God’s commands
A people who strictly follow the law
questions.correctAnswer: A rebellious people who follow their own thoughts
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:2 describes them as 'a rebellious people, which walketh in a way that was not good, after their own thoughts.' This highlights human sinfulness and rebellion against God’s will, consistent with Jeremiah 17:9 and Romans 1:21 where humanity's sinful nature is explained.

questions.question: In Isaiah 65:3, what specific sinful practices provoke God to anger?
options: Sacrificing in gardens and burning incense on altars of brick
Giving tithes without faith
Praying with insincere hearts
Ignoring the Sabbath day
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrificing in gardens and burning incense on altars of brick
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:3 condemns the people who 'sacrificeth in gardens, and burneth incense upon altars of brick,' indicating idolatrous worship outside of God's appointed places. This is similar to Ezekiel 6:13 and Jeremiah 7:31, where improper worship and idolatry provoke God's wrath.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 65:4, what abominable behaviors are described among the people?
options: Dwelling among graves and eating swine's flesh
Keeping the Sabbath and honoring parents
Sacrificing animals in the temple
Offering thanksgiving sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Dwelling among graves and eating swine's flesh
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:4 refers to those 'which remain among the graves, and lodge in the monuments, which eat swine’s flesh, and broth of abominable things is in their vessels,' illustrating defilement and rebellion against Mosaic purity laws (Leviticus 11). This reflects deeper spiritual corruption as seen in Ezekiel 22:26.

questions.question: How does God describe those who say, 'Stand by thyself, come not near to me; for I am holier than thou' in Isaiah 65:5?
options: As a smoke in His nose, a fire that burns all day
As humble and repentant sinners
As righteous and acceptable to God
As seekers of true holiness
questions.correctAnswer: As a smoke in His nose, a fire that burns all day
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:5 portrays the proud and self-righteous as 'a smoke in my nose, a fire that burneth all the day,' symbolizing how their arrogance provokes God constantly. This concept is echoed in Proverbs 6:16-19, which condemns pride, and James 4:6, which states God resists the proud but gives grace to the humble.

questions.question: What does God promise in Isaiah 65:8 regarding His servants amid judgment?
options: He will preserve a blessing like new wine in a cluster
He will destroy all without exception
He will forget His covenant promises
He will leave them to their own devices
questions.correctAnswer: He will preserve a blessing like new wine in a cluster
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:8 uses the metaphor of new wine found in a grape cluster which should not be destroyed because it contains a blessing, illustrating God's mercy in preserving His faithful servants during judgment. This is consistent with the faithful remnant theme in Romans 11:5 and Zechariah 8:12.

questions.question: What inheritance does God promise to Jacob’s seed and Judah’s inheritor in Isaiah 65:9?
options: They will inherit His mountains and dwell securely
They will wander without a homeland
They will be rejected and scattered
They will lose their covenant status
questions.correctAnswer: They will inherit His mountains and dwell securely
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:9 promises that the elect will inherit God's mountains and dwell there securely, symbolizing a restored and blessed kingdom. This echoes God's covenant promises in Genesis 17:8 and the eschatological hope in Revelation 21:1-3.

questions.question: What consequence does God declare for those who forsake Him and forget His holy mountain in Isaiah 65:11-12?
options: They will be numbered to the sword and face slaughter
They will receive abundant blessings
They will find peace and rest
They will be exalted above others
questions.correctAnswer: They will be numbered to the sword and face slaughter
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:11-12 pronounces judgment on those who forsake the Lord, promising they will be 'numbered to the sword' and face destruction because they rejected God's call, paralleling Deuteronomy 28:15 and Hebrews 10:26-31 about consequences of persistent rebellion.

questions.question: How does God contrast the experiences of His servants with the rebellious in Isaiah 65:13-14?
options: Servants will eat, drink, and rejoice; rebels will be hungry, thirsty, and ashamed
Both will suffer equally
Rebels will prosper while servants suffer
Servants will mourn and rebels will celebrate
questions.correctAnswer: Servants will eat, drink, and rejoice; rebels will be hungry, thirsty, and ashamed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:13-14 contrasts God's servants who enjoy provision and joy with rebels who experience hunger, thirst, shame, and sorrow. This motif of blessing for the faithful and judgment for the wicked is consistent with Psalm 37:19 and Matthew 25:31-46.

questions.question: What new identity does God say He will give His servants in Isaiah 65:15?
options: He will call His servants by another name
They will keep their old names
They will be known by their earthly lineage
They will be called rebels
questions.correctAnswer: He will call His servants by another name
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:15 declares that God will 'call his servants by another name,' signifying a new identity and relationship with God, which reflects New Testament themes of being a new creation in Christ (2 Corinthians 5:17) and receiving a new name (Revelation 2:17).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 65:16, on whom will people bless and swear in the new order God establishes?
options: The God of truth
Their own strength
The gods of the nations
Their earthly rulers
questions.correctAnswer: The God of truth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:16 states that those who bless or swear will do so 'in the God of truth,' emphasizing God's unchanging faithfulness. This aligns with Exodus 34:6, Psalm 31:5, and Hebrews 6:18, which affirm God's truthfulness and dependability.

questions.question: What eschatological promise is given in Isaiah 65:17 about the new heavens and new earth?
options: The former things will not be remembered or come to mind
The old earth will remain forever
There will be no change from the current order
The past sins will be continually remembered
questions.correctAnswer: The former things will not be remembered or come to mind
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:17 promises God will create 'new heavens and a new earth' where former things are forgotten, paralleling Revelation 21:1 and 2 Peter 3:13, which portray God’s final restoration and renewal of creation.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 65:20 say about the lifespan and fate of the righteous and the sinner in the new age?
options: The child will die at 100 years old; the sinner at 100 will be accursed
All will live exactly 70 years
The sinner will live longer than the righteous
There will be no death at all
questions.correctAnswer: The child will die at 100 years old; the sinner at 100 will be accursed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:20 speaks of an extended lifespan where the child dying at 100 is a tragedy and the sinner at 100 is accursed, symbolizing the rarity of death and presence of judgment. This reflects the idealized longevity in Genesis 6:3 and eschatological justice in Revelation 20:12-15.

questions.question: What assurance does God give concerning the labor and inheritance of His people in Isaiah 65:21-23?
options: They will build, inhabit, plant, and not labor in vain
Their labor will be stolen by others
They will wander without a settled home
Their work will bring them trouble and sorrow
questions.correctAnswer: They will build, inhabit, plant, and not labor in vain
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:21-23 promises that God's people will enjoy the fruits of their labor, living securely and without frustration, reflecting God's blessing in Deuteronomy 28:12 and the future hope described in Psalm 128:2.

questions.question: How does God describe His responsiveness to His people’s prayers in Isaiah 65:24?
options: He will answer before they call and hear while they speak
He will delay answers until they prove their worth
He will ignore their requests
He will only answer after long waiting
questions.correctAnswer: He will answer before they call and hear while they speak
questions.explanation: Isaiah 65:24 declares God's immediate and attentive response to His servants, illustrating His omniscience and care. This is consistent with 1 John 5:14 and Psalm 34:15, which affirm God’s readiness to answer the prayers of the righteous.
